info.headline: Flood Advisory issued February 03 at 6:39PM EST until February 05 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in North Carolina... French Broad River At Blantyre affecting Transylvania and Henderson Counties. .Approximately 2-4 inches of rain has fallen across the upper French Broad watershed over the past 24 hours, causing within-bank rises along the French Broad River and associated tributaries. While this rainfall is not enough to cause out-of-bank conditions, additional rainfall is moving in from the west and is expected to persist through Friday morning. Some of this rain will be heavy and an additional 2-3" of rainfall is likely. This additional rain will increase already elevated streamflows and will likely cause some nuisance flood conditions within the watershed, including along the French Broad River below Rosman to Brevard, Etowah, Blantyre, and Horse Shoe. If rainfall exceeds 3" overnight, Minor Flooding may occur and begin to impact some roadways. This may require an upgrade to a Flood Warning. Please stay weather aware tonight and monitor the latest forecasts and stream levels for up-to-date information. ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING TO SATURDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...French Broad River At Blantyre. * WHEN...From this evening to Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Minor Flood Stage. Farmland flooding continues on both sides of the French Broad River. Floodwaters begin to impact boat access areas at Grove Bridge Rd. and Crab Creek Rd. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:30 PM EST Thursday the stage was 10.3 feet and rising steadily. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest between 15.5 feet and 16.5 feet by tomorrow evening. - Action/Advisory Stage is 15.0 feet. - Minor Flood Stage is 16.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: If you are in the advisory area, remain alert to possible flooding or the possibility of the advisory being upgraded to a Warning. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp
